Topic.Title: Amazon earnings don't reflect the bigger picture

Message.Msg: Since you shorts are too lazy to read the article, I'll sum it up for you. "sales were up 29 percent year-over-year to $12.8 billion". See you at $300.

Message.Title: Are Amazon Revenues Real?
Message.Msg: One of the questions not much asked is how Amazon, long operating on a vast retail scale, is able to match its expenses so closely to revenues, quarter after quarter. Generating a profit is not so much the issue since this is a revenue growth story, but how they have avoided gushing red ink is truly a remarkable feat. I cannot recall ever seeing a retail company account like this, with such precision. It is incredible! But is it true?

Topic.Title: Amazon earnings don't reflect the bigger picture

Message.Msg: But folks have to remember this guy (timber) is the same guy who said "this stock will never go over $90 again". It exceeded that $90 only months later. This is fine, but then he comes back and tells us that "never" to him meant several months. It did not mean "never" in the literal sense. OK, so for his admittedly "personal" odd-ball sense of accelerated time, a century translates into only 1-2 years literal terms. Amazon is investing for 1-2 years and it is trading at 20x 1-2 year estimates. Pretty cheap. You just need to have the right filters in dealing with timber's predictions. "Never" and "century" don't mean the same thing to him as they do to people who speak normal English.

Topic.Title: No one will say the 'T' word, but Internet sales tax is all but inevitable

Message.Msg: "Amazon, as explained in detail here, is willing to give up its sales tax advantage because it plans to build distribution centers around the country in an effort to offer same-day shipping and slay brick and mortar shoppers that way.)" What this writer missed was the fact that it isn't just about faster shipping, it is the fact that once tax is no longer an issue you can put a distribution center just miles out of big markets like Los Angeles (like San Bernadino) and save on shipping costs on packages that used to have to be sent from Nevada several hundred miles away. So if shipping costs are coming way down and customers are getting orders faster how is this supposed to help shorts again?
SSH @ 234.49. 1K lot

Message.Msg: So why do they fight so hard to stop states from forcing them to collect sales tax. They say one thing and do another.

Message.Title: Is amazon selling any kindle fires anymore?
Message.Msg: Is that why they put the video on ipad? If an consumer can buy a tablet from anyone and still put amazon so called content on it, there will be no reason anyone would buy the tablet from amazon. For one thing, buying amazon tablet will limit you to what they offer as available apps, not the Google's marketplace that has tons more apps. Amazon will never be able to match others like Google and apple with hardware. So if you are in market to buy a cheap tablet, you will either wait to see what amazon will offer in few months or buy the better tablets out there right now, such as Nexus 7.

Message.Title: VIX is crashing DOW 300 points by lunch
Message.Msg: after Euro close

Topic.Title: No one will say the 'T' word, but Internet sales tax is all but inevitable

Message.Msg: "So why do they fight so hard to stop states from forcing them to collect sales tax." It is often easier just to keep things the way they are. Also, the longer you put these things off and the larger you can grow before making the change, the more you will benefit from the economies of scale. And there is an initial level of capital investment required that is a big part of this investment cycle. But it is temporary. I can see you did not do your math. At the basic UPS rates Amazon will be able to cut about 11% from their shipping expenses. 25% savings for shipments requiring faster shipping times. Try it out for yourself. The example I tried out was for sending a package from Fernly, Nevada where Amazon has distribution centers now and sending the same package from San Bernadino where a new fulfillment center mentioned in the article is opening both to an L.A. zip code 90024 which is where a lot of Amazon customers live in that area. http://www.theupsstore.com/ctc/pages/estimate-shipping-cost.aspx

Topic.Title: Amazon earnings don't reflect the bigger picture

Message.Msg: "There are only so many customers willing to buy online..period." As older people die off, and younger people replace them, we'll have more people shopping online. One reason to shop online is to avoid xmas crowds. I buy stuff from Amazon because it's just easier than going to the store. Amazon increases sales 30% / year, it doesn't take long for that to amount to some real money.

Topic.Title: No one will say the 'T' word, but Internet sales tax is all but inevitable

Message.Msg: Except if it is 25% of 10-20% of sales you may end up simply keeping prices practically flat (which might be not giving consumers the 2-3% discount you otherwise might have). Last quarter Amazon increased some of the fees they charge to 3P sellers. There are more ways to deal with taxes than simply raising prices the consumer pays. If customers are already used to saving 15% buying from Amazon they probably aren't going to mind saving only 12-13% with the orders coming a day or two faster than before.

Topic.Title: No one will say the 'T' word, but Internet sales tax is all but inevitable

Message.Msg: One thing you left out of your "logic". It is cheaper to ship a lot of stuff in bulk to a location very near the end customer than to have to ship it to somewhere very far from your customer and then send it in a small package all the way to your customer some distant and remote location. They won't "slay" all stores, but as we can see they already slayed Borders and Circuit City, and for all intents and purposes Barnes and Noble. For Amazon to wipe out all the shorts here they hardly need to "slay" all retail stores. Just of few of the major chains like say maybe BBY will do for now.

Topic.Title: Greater Fools and Great Liars

Message.Msg: here is the difintion since you seem confused: Definition of 'Greater Fool Theory' A theory that states it is possible to make money by buying securities, whether overvalued or not, and later selling them at a profit because there will always be someone (a bigger or greater fool) who is willing to pay the higher price. Investopedia explains 'Greater Fool Theory' When acting in accordance with the greater fool theory, an investor buys questionable securities without any regard to their quality, but with the hope of quickly selling them off to another investor (the greater fool), who might also be hoping to flip them quickly. Unfortunately, speculative bubbles always burst eventually, leading to a rapid depreciation in share price due to the selloff. Read more: http://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/greaterfooltheory.asp#ixzz22VK4hI8f

Topic.Title: Chalk? you disappear again like last Friday?

Message.Msg: You cant play VIX. Its an uninvestbale index. The VIX futures are a completely different stary. These futures funds are the easiest money making scam on earth. VIX could rise to 40 and VXX would still be under 25 as of now. Its value is destroyed daily by contango in the VIX futures as well as Uncle Benny supporting the markets to the point that there is no need for portfolio protection through options at the present time. The options spreads are what change the VIX and there are no signs of this support changing

Topic.Title: How AMZN Max Pain works

Message.Msg: These employments numbers hit the right spot for the bulls. AMZN trades with the Nas and the many index funds. The employment numbers were good, yet employment rate increased to 8.3% which leaves the door open for the Fed and QE. If the employment number fell to 8.1% instead, then the markets would have been 200pts in the red and AMZN at $225. These are the breaks. I sold some naked Aug $220's at close and bought some Aug $225 PUTS, which were a steal at $1.49

Message.Msg: many states drop out the sale tax for a week/end before school starts, is that good for amzn ? In Florida, it starts today, will people still want to go amazon even if it free shipping? how is that going to change amzn's er, minus 1c ?

Message.Msg: $250 with current guidance would be a tough goal. AMZN is trading with the Nas right now. The Nasdaq would have to go up another few hundred points for AMZN to hit $250. 1/3 of AMZN holders are retail, so there is going to be a lot of profit taking at several levels before $250 is reached. Personally I am betting on a pullback to $220, but you never know.
